**Title:**
*The Yellow Emperor’s Yinfu Jing with Interlinear Commentary and Exegesis*
(*Huangdi Yinfu Jing Jiashong Jiezhu*)

**Author:**
Compiled by Daoist Wang Jie (style name Daoyuan) of the Yuan-Ming period. Three scrolls.
Source text: *Zhengtong Daozang*, *Tongzhen* section, *Yujue* category.

---

**Preface to the *Yellow Emperor’s Yinfu Jing* with Interlinear Commentary and Exegesis**

*"Heaven follows humanity, humanity follows Heaven"*—this is the purpose of the *Yinfu Jing*.

In antiquity, the Yellow Emperor, earnest in his devotion to the Dao, ascended Mount Kongtong to pay homage to Guangchengzi and inquire about the ultimate Way, receiving the secret precepts of returning to eternal life. Later, upon Mount Emei, he again paid homage to Huangren, who imparted the *Wuyaya-Sanyi* scriptures, which he kept secret and cultivated, thereby ascending to the highest immortality. Worried that future generations might lose the true teachings, he composed the *Yinfu Jing* in three sections—upper, middle, and lower—to correspond with the Three Powers (*san cai*), elucidating the marvels of *jing* (essence), *qi*, and *shen* (spirit) in their utmost refinement.

Yet fearing that mortals might not grasp the principle of return, he first declared: *"Observe the Dao of Heaven, grasp Heaven’s movements, and exhaust them."* This is the overarching framework of the three sections of the *Yinfu Jing*.

To know the Dao of Heaven, one must know the Dao of humanity;
to know the Dao of humanity, one must know the Dao of the Elixir (*dandao*);
to know the Dao of the Elixir, one must grasp the mechanics of yin-yang motion and stillness;
to grasp those mechanics, one must know the principles of internal and external return.

Knowing these principles, one refines lead and mercury without missing the proper moment, and governs the elixir fire without failing to observe its signs. As the text states: *"Cutting off the single source of profit, the adept’s effort is tenfold; three returns of day and night, the adept’s effort is ten-thousandfold."* This further teaches that the essence of cultivating the True lies in maintaining an unshaken resolve to gather and refine the mind and body, and secondarily, in applying unremitting *chou-tian* (withdrawal and addition) techniques without interruption.

The Way of *Quanzhen* is nothing else:
First, *jing* must be complete;
Second, *qi* must be complete;
Third, *shen* must be complete.

Fixing the gaze refines the spirit;
returning the hearing refines the essence;
sealing the speech refines the *qi*.

When these three completions and three truths are realized, they naturally merge within, and the True Fire polishes the embryo, forming a golden fetus. After ten months of work, yin is exhausted and yang is pure. At this moment, the fetus is shed, the spirit transforms, and the adept manifests without bounds, transcending birth and death to become an indestructible golden body—this is what is meant by *huan dan* (returning the Elixir).

I say that this text is concise yet profound in meaning. Those who fail to comprehend its teachings may seek explanations externally, straying from the Dao, and thus incur the guilt of presumption and madness. Therefore, I have sequentially explicated each passage of the Master’s secret precepts, supplemented with verse and verification, revealing the hidden mechanisms, awaiting those of like mind. I do not presume to exhaust the subject, but hope this may serve as an aid for beginners.

**The *Yin Fu Jing* Exegesis by Master Róngrán Zǐ Wáng Dàoyuán**

**Preface by Master Róngrán Zǐ Wáng Dàoyuán of Nánchāng’s Xiū River**

*"Heaven begets, heaven slays—this is the Dao’s principle.*
*In worldly terms, heaven begets yang, heaven slays yin. One yin, one yang—this is the Dao; one begetting, one slaying—this is principle.*

*Heaven begets in spring, when all things arise from yang—this is Heaven’s *ren* (benevolence).
*Heaven slays in autumn, when all things withdraw into yin—this is Heaven’s *yì* (righteousness).
*The waxing and waning of yin and yang—this is the Dao’s principle.*

*Thus, the Sage observes Heaven’s Dao, holds principle in mind, and governs the people with *wuwei* (non-action)—this is the Sage’s *ren*.
*He establishes the Five Punishments to harmonize the laws of the world—this is the Sage’s *yì*.
*The embodiment and function of *ren* and *yì*—this is the Sage’s Dao.*

*Speaking of Dao’s application: whenever the Winter Solstice arrives within one’s body, one must seal the pass and attain stillness, disperse the mind into fire, refine essence into *qi*, and advance the yang fire upward from the *Tai Xuang Gong* (Supreme Darkness Palace) to the *Nan Gong* (Southern Palace)—this is the principle of Heaven’s begetting.
*From this point onward, as yang reaches its peak and declines, a single yin arises beneath the five yangs, and one must then gather yang and withdraw the *Yin Fu* (Yin Symbol).
*Descending from the Jade Mountain to the Upper Capital, then to the Heavy Tower, sending it to the *Kun* position and halting—here, the martial fire is kindled to temper yin into yang—this is the principle of Heaven’s slaying.
*To circulate this within the body, continuous as if ever-present—is this not the Dao’s principle?

*Master Shao said:*
*‘When Qian meets Xun, observe the Moon Cavern;
When Earth meets Thunder, tread upon the Heavenly Root.’
*The Heavenly Root and Moon Cavern drift in leisure—
Thirty-six palaces are all spring.*

*Thus it is said:*
*‘The yang dragon and yin tiger coil in rotation,
Heaven’s hidden mechanisms of life and death unfold naturally.
Refined, the true seed of One-Nine emerges,
Within the vessel, spring overflows—Dao eternal.’*

---

**Heaven and Earth are the thieves of all things;
All things are thieves of humanity;
Humanity is the thief of all things.**

*Heaven and Earth are the thieves of all things*—this means Heaven and Earth generate all things, and the life and form of all things are formed by the interplay of yin and yang’s transformation. At every thought and impulse, Heaven and Earth know.
*Those who do good are protected by ghosts and spirits;
Those who do evil are struck by thunder and punishment*—this is how Heaven and Earth govern all things.

*All things are thieves of humanity*—this means all things arise alongside humanity, and within the human body dwell eighty-four thousand worms. Briefly stated: internally, the five viscera are consumed by *qí* and *huí* worms; externally, the skin is attacked by lice and fleas. As *Tan Jing Sheng*’s *Book of Transformation* says:
*‘The worms that camp within the belly
Plunder my vital *qi*, melt my spirit-soul,
Steal my flavors, yet live by them.’*
This is how all things steal from humanity.

*Humanity is the thief of all things*—this means humanity is the most refined of all things, encompassing within one mind the principles of all things. It learns from Heaven and Earth to know transformation, from spiders to weave nets, from bees to establish hierarchy, from moles to institute rites, from phoenixes to compose music, from ants to arrange armies. The Sage can take the principles of all things and perfect them within the self—this is how humanity steals from all things.

*In summary, the generation of Heaven, Earth, and humanity all lies within the Great Transformation. Forms steal from forms, things deceive things—none of this is outside the influence of yin and yang, the Five Phases’ *qi*. Only the Daoist, who comprehends the Three Thefts and transcends yin and yang, is free from the Three Corpses’ plunder.*

*Students should ponder this deeply.*

*Ode:*
*Heaven, Earth, and humanity share in all things’ birth,
Each family, each orifice holds its own spirit.
Forms steal from forms through yin and yang’s transformation—
The enlightened transcend the mundane, entering the Supreme Clarity.
The Three Thefts are resolved, the Three Powers are at peace.*

*This follows the earlier discussion of the Three Thefts, thus it says:*
*The Three Thefts resolved, the Three Powers secure*—this refers to the enlightened one, whose single nature illuminates all principles, who can discern that the body’s four elements are but yin and yang, the Five Phases’ *qi*, artificially combined. Unbound by form, one secretly practices the Symbol Fire to refine form and spirit. When spirit condenses and *qi* solidifies, this is the Golden Elixir’s great medicine, capable of slaying the Three Corpses’ worms. Once the Three Thefts are extinguished, the Three Powers naturally settle.

*As Master Shao said:*
*‘Having known all things are within me,
Why would I separately establish the Three Powers?’*

*Zhang Zǐyáng said:*
*‘Pursue the Two *Qi* along the Yellow Path,
Unite the Three Natures in the Primordial Palace.
When spirit is whole, there is no need for sleep;
When *qi* is whole, there is no need for food;
When essence is whole, there is no need for desire.
When practice reaches this point, how could the Three Powers be unstable?’*

*Ode:*
*The Three Thefts and Three Powers are complete within the body,
The Heart-Sovereign turns all things, each returning to root.
When Heaven and Earth’s positions are fixed, demons are subdued,
The myriad lands enjoy peace under the Sage’s grace.*

*Thus it is said:*
*‘Eat in season, and the hundred limbs harmonize.
Stir the mechanism, and all transformations settle.’*

*This further elaborates on the Three Powers being secure, thus it says:*
*‘Eat in season, and the hundred limbs harmonize’*—this means the practitioner must daily regulate the five viscera, ensuring meals are taken at their proper times. If no time is lost, then the three hundred sixty bones and blood-*qi* flow unimpeded throughout the body, with no place unnourished, and illness cannot arise. Having secured bodily health, one can then nurture spirit and embrace *qi*, dwelling eternally in the Central Field, drawing from the *Hua Chi* (Flower Pond) and *Yu Ye* (Jade Liquid) to irrigate the sacred root—its shoots will naturally flourish.
*As Laozi said:*
*‘When the Dao prevails in the world, even warhorses are used for manure—
I alone differ from others, valuing the Mother’s nourishment.’*

*‘Stir the mechanism, and all transformations settle’*—this means when the first yang stirs, one must immediately turn the Dipper’s handle to respond to it. Each practice of the Dao will make the myriad spirits within the body feel at ease.*"

「The Pure Yang True Person’s *Alchemical Poems* state:
*Within the vast Dao of Heaven and Earth, alone I dwell,
From head to toe, each step refines the Primordial Essence’s work.
With nimble skill, I wield the Dipper’s Cross,
Boldly overturning the Southern Star’s mechanism—my *qi* as fierce as steel.*

*When the myriad spirits wail and demons lament, the golden cauldron cracks,
As roosters take flight and dogs dissolve, the jade furnace stands empty.*

*How can the common man seek such ordinary ways?
The Dao’s subtleties are boundless—its mysteries fathomless.*

*The *Alchemical Canon* says:
*‘Deliberate well—this is wondrous indeed!
Each dawn, I urge the *Zi Xia* [Purple Cloud] Cup to rise.’*

*If one binds the Earthly *Po* [embryo/soul] with precision,
The Heavenly *Hun* [ethereal soul] will naturally come to bless longevity.*

*Thus it is said.*

*Praise:
*To cultivate the True, one must balance food and breath.
A single *qi* harmonizes the Five Organs, cleansing them all.
The Golden Elixir refines the form, the Divine Fire tempers the spirit—
Every pore in the body radiates brilliance.*

*Men know the spirit’s spirit,
But fail to grasp the source of the non-spirit’s spirit.*

*The spirit, for its name, is *Ling* [numinous],
And *Xing* [inherent nature].*

*Before the parents were born, its beginning was not known;
After the parents were born, its end was not seen.*

*Most numinous, most sacred,
Most profound, most subtle—
It encompasses all forms,
It encompasses all spirits,
Unborn, unending,
Neither square nor round.*

*Thus the Pure and True True Person said:
*‘This spirit is not the spirit of deliberation,
But one that stands equal with the Primordial Origin.’*

*This passage speaks of how the student’s daily cultivation must first focus on clarifying inherent nature.
Within the heart-mind, one must always maintain purity and stillness,
Never allowing even a thread of private desire to obstruct it,
Nor clinging to forms while seeking the mysterious.*

*If one merely conjures an intention,
The spirit ceases to be spirit.*

*The *Sutra* says:
*‘The human spirit loves clarity, yet the heart disturbs it—
The spirit’s full brilliance lies in the heart’s emptiness, profound silence, and containing the True.
It shares its essence with the Great Void,
Its luminosity with the sun and moon.’*

*In all interactions with affairs and beings,
One must let inherent nature respond spontaneously,
Turning with the natural flow—
Thus the Three Realms are traversed in harmony,
And this is why one does not know the non-spirit’s source of spirit.*

*The True Person said:
*‘It cannot be seen, yet when called, it responds.’*

*The *Diamond Sutra* declares:
*‘If one seeks the Tathāgata through form and appearance,
Or through sound and voice,
They tread the wrong path and cannot see the Buddha.’*

*These words are complete.*

*Praise:
*A single point of Primordial Spirit is the ultimate numinous.
When the spirit knows itself, it is no longer true.
If one awakens to the spirit’s empty essence,
The resplendent void shines without a trace of cloud.*

*The sun and moon have their cycles,
The small and great have their limits.
From here arise the sacred works,
From here emerge the divine luminosities.*

*This follows the previous explanation of clarifying inherent nature,
And now reveals the method of cultivating life.*

*Having secured the dwelling of inherent nature,
One must then attend to the life-gate.*

*If one can cultivate both inherent nature and life,
Only then does the form and spirit attain perfect harmony.*

*The method of cultivating life is such:
The student may observe the Dao of Heaven,
Where the sun and moon revolve, marking the Winter and Summer Solstices,
And the Yin-Yang equilibrium at the Spring and Autumn Equinoxes.
Days accumulate into months,
Months accumulate into years—
Thus the sun and moon have their cycles,
And the small and great have their limits.*

*Has it not been heard?
The sun belongs to Yang, the moon to Yin;
The moon itself has no light, but borrows the sun’s.*

*At the month’s dark and new phases,
The Great Yin and Great Yang meet in the same palace,
And the moon, at this time, is dark and without light;
From the second to the third day, the moon gradually departs from the sun,
And the sun’s light shines upon it, generating a small brilliance—
The *Hun* grows, the *Po* diminishes.*

*By the eighth day, night and day share equal light—
This is called the Upper Crescent.*
*From here onward, until the fifteenth day at night,
The moon faces the sun, its light full and great—
At this point, the *Hun* reaches its peak, and the *Po* emerges.*

*From the sixteenth to the seventeenth days onward,
The *Po* grows, the *Hun* fades,
And the moon’s light gradually wanes.*

*By the twenty-third day at night,
The light is equally divided below—
This is called the Lower Crescent.*
*From here, until the thirtieth day at night,
The moon’s light fades completely, returning once more to darkness.*

*Thus it cycles endlessly, without end—
A natural and effortless movement of Heaven’s Dao.*
*Therefore, the great cultivator applies this principle within his own body,
And refines the *Fire Elucidation* [周天火候] of the Heavenly Cycle.*

*The sun and moon spoken of here are the spirit and *qi*,
Water and Fire,
Lead and Mercury,
And inherent nature and emotions.*

*When making the elixir,
One must merge spirit with *qi*,
Consolidating its foundation within,
And letting the spirit soar forth in the *Yin* [Tiger] Hour.
By the *Shen* [Monkey] Hour, one must increase the fire,
As the sun’s light shines upon the moon—
Gradually, the brilliance grows and strengthens.*

*The essence transforms into *qi*,
Directly entering the *Cinnabar Field* [泥丸],
As the moon faces the sun—
Following this, Yin emerges,
And according to the *Green Maiden Transmission* [《青女传》],
The elixir is withdrawn into the Earthly Palace,
Where the sun and moon join as one—
The elixir begins to form, small at first,
But with deep cultivation, it grows great—
Thus it is said: ‘The sun and moon have their cycles,
And the small and great have their limits.’*

*Diligently gather, diligently refine,
Timely cook and temper—
The True Embryo flourishes,
Wisdom and insight open wide—
Thus it is said: ‘From here arise the sacred works,
From here emerge the divine luminosities.’*

*Praise:
*The sun and moon cycle endlessly, their work applied—
The elixir’s essence is born from the *Dharma-qi* [梵气].*
*From the subtle to the manifest, the spirit transcends the sacred,
And within the fire, lotuses bloom one by one.*

*As for stealing the mechanism,
No one in the world can see or know it.*
*The noble man attains it and secures his body,
The petty man gains it and risks his life.*

*This follows the previous explanation of refining the sun and moon within one’s body,
And thus attaining the sacred works and divine luminosities—
Hence it is said:*

*‘The stealing here refers not to the worldly thievery of common men,
But to the method of refining the Heavenly Cycle’s elixir-fire—
In a single breath’s time, one can surpass a year’s transformation of Heaven and Earth.’*

*The *Alchemical Canon* says:
*‘When the Five Phases flow in order,
A tiger emerges from water;
When the Five Phases are inverted,
A dragon arises from fire.’*

*Those who practice this Dao
Cannot be confined by Heaven and Earth,
Nor bound by the *Bazi* [六十甲子, sixty-year Heavenly Stem-Earthly Branch cycle].*
*Thus, the great cultivator is a thief beyond Heaven and Earth.’*

Zhang Wǔyáng said:

*"The practice is easy, but the medicine is not distant—
Is this not the very essence of the ‘thief’s method’?*

This ‘thief’s method’ is supremely simple, yet supremely subtle—
It is the form without form, the image without image.
Thus, none under Heaven can see it, none can know it.

The noble one who attains it
Is humble, retiring, and unassuming,
Nurtures simplicity and preserves authenticity;
Discards sharp intellect, relying solely on virtue as his body;
Diminishes further, blending with the mundane and dust;
Responds naturally to all that comes, without joy or anger.
He never flaunts his Dao—
This is how he holds it close to his essence.

As *Laozi* says:
*'I have three treasures, guarding and preserving them:
First, compassion;
Second, frugality;
Third, not daring to lead the world.'*
And again:
*'The highest virtue is without virtue—
Thus, it is truly virtuous.'*

The petty one, if he attains this Dao,
Will instead flaunt it, unable to conceal himself.
He grows arrogant, self-aggrandizing,
Boasting and vainglorious,
Deceiving others and scornful of the Way,
Completely without restraint,
With shallow virtue and shallow conduct—
All despise him.

Such a man has never failed to court harm
And risk his life—
Like Páng Juān’s kind.

The *Classical Text* says:
*'Those who praise themselves are blind,
Those who insist on being right are unilluminated,
Those who boast of their achievements gain no merit,
Those who brag of their virtue do not endure,
The overbearing meet no natural end.'*

Confucius thus said:
*'The petty one reverses the Mean—
The petty one has no restraint.'*

Is this not true speech?
The student should carefully examine this.

「The *Preface* states:
The *Burning Mountain* [1] seals the Dao of Heaven’s theft,
The *Great Symbol* [2] hides the subtle mysteries of the Way.
The virtuous one attains it and retreats to preserve himself,
While the petty one, once he gains it, acts recklessly.

*Yellow Emperor’s Obscure Precepts* [3]—*Interpretation of the Interspersed Precepts*—[4] therein concludes:
*Yellow Emperor’s Obscure Precepts* [3]—*Interpretation of the Interspersed Precepts*—[4]—[5] *Master Rúndàoyuān* of *Nánchāng Xiūjiāng* [6] annotates:
Heaven’s birth and Heaven’s death are the Way’s principle.
Speaking in terms of worldly law,
Heaven’s birth is *yang* [7], Heaven’s death is *yin* [8];
One *yin* and one *yang* is called the Way,
One birth and one death is called principle.

Heaven’s birth occurs in spring,
When all things arise from *yang*—Heaven’s benevolence;
Heaven’s death occurs in autumn,
When all things withdraw into *yin*—Heaven’s righteousness.
The ebb and flow of *yin* and *yang* are the Way’s principle.

Thus, the sage observes Heaven’s Way,
Holds principle within his heart,
And transforms the people of the world through non-action—this is the sage’s benevolence;
With the five punishments [9], he harmonizes the laws of the world—this is the sage’s righteousness.
Benevolence and righteousness in essence and application are the sage’s Way.

Speaking in terms of application,
When one encounters the winter solstice [10] within his body,
He must close the gate [11] and remain still,
Sending his mind aloft to transform fire,
Refining essence into *qi*,
Advancing the *yang* fire,
From the *Tàixuān Palace* [12] drawing upward to the *Nán Palace* [13]—this is Heaven’s birth principle.

Once this is done, the *yang* reaches its peak and declines,
So when one *yin* arises beneath the five *yang*,
He must withdraw the *yang* and suppress the *Obscure Precept* of *yin*.
From *Yùshān* [14] descending to *Chónglóu* [15],
Conveying it to the *Kūn* [16] position and halting,
Igniting the *Martial Fire* [17] to temper and refine,
Cooking *yin* into *yang*—this is Heaven’s death principle.

Cultivating within one’s body,
Continuously as if sustained—
Is this not the Way’s principle?

*Master Shào* [18] says:
When *Qián* [19] meets *Xùn* [20], observe the *Moon Cavern* [21];
When earth encounters *léi* [22], tread upon Heaven’s root.
Heaven’s root and Moon Cavern come and go at leisure,
Thirty-six palaces [23] are all spring.
This is what is meant.

The *Preface* states:
The *yang* dragon and *yin* tiger intertwine in circles,
Heaven’s birth and death principles unfold naturally.
Refining yields the *One Nine* [24] true seed,
A caldron full of spring—Dao stretches endlessly.

Heaven and Earth are the thieves of all things;
All things are thieves of man;
Man is the thief of all things.
Heaven and Earth are the thieves of all things—
This means Heaven and Earth generate all things,
And the vitality of all things,
None escape the *yin-yang* transformations that form their bodies.
Every thought and intention—Heaven and Earth know them all.
Doing good brings protection from spirits and gods;
Doing evil invites punishment by thunder and lightning—
This is how Heaven and Earth treat all things.

All things are thieves of man—
This means all things arise alongside man,
And within the human body, eight thousand four hundred insects [25] thrive.
Speaking briefly,
Internally, the five viscera [26] are consumed by *wēngzhì* [27] worms,
Externally, the skin is attacked by fleas and lice.
As *Tán Jǐngshēng*’s *Book of Transformation* [28] says:
*Wēngzhì* [29] insects, the worms of the belly,
Struggle with my *qi* and essence,
Melt my spirit and soul,
Steal my nourishment,
And yet sustain their own lives.
This is how all things steal from man.

Man is the thief of all things—
This means man is the most refined of all things,
One mind encompassing the principles of all things,
Learning from Heaven and Earth to know transformations,
Learning from the *spider* to weave nets,
Learning from the *bee* to establish hierarchy,
Learning from the *gopher* to create rituals,
Learning from the *phoenix* to compose music,
Learning from the *ant* to arrange armies and formations.
The sage can extract the principles of all things to perfect himself—
This is how man steals from all things.

In summary,
The birth of Heaven, Earth, and man,
All lie within the Great Transformation [30],
Each form stealing from another,
Each thing deceiving another,
None but the *yin-yang* and Five Phases *qi* [31] acting thus.
Only the Daoist who understands the Three Thefts [32],
Transcending beyond *yin-yang*,
Will escape the harm of the Three Corpses [33] stealing from him.
The student should ponder this well.

The *Preface* states:
Heaven, Earth, and man share the birth of all things,
Each family and orifice holds its own spirit.
Forms steal from forms through *yin-yang* transformations,
The enlightened transcend the mundane to enter *Tàiqīng* [34].
The Three Thefts [35] being understood,
The Three Powers [36] are at peace.
This follows the previous discourse on the Three Thefts,
Therefore it says:
When the Three Thefts are understood,
The Three Powers are at peace—
This refers to the Daoist,
Whose singular nature is awakened and illuminated,
Whose myriad principles are unified,
Who can discern that the body’s Four Great Elements [37]
Are but *yin-yang* and Five Phases *qi* falsely combined.
He is not bound by form,
But secretly practices the *Obscure Precept* fire
To refine body and spirit.
When spirit condenses and *qi* solidifies,
This is called the *Great Elixir* [38],
A medicine capable of annihilating the Three Corpses [33].
Once the Three Thefts are extinguished,
The Three Powers naturally rest.

As *Master Shào* says:
When one knows all things are complete within me,
Why would he separately establish the Three Powers?

*Zhāng Zǐyáng* [39] thus said:
*"Chasing the Two Qì [40] along the Yellow Dao [41],
Uniting the Three Natures [42] in the Primordial Palace [43],
The spirit is whole and does not crave sleep,
The *qi* is whole and does not crave food,
The essence is whole and does not crave desire—
When cultivation reaches this point,
What fear is there that the Three Powers will not be at peace?"*

The *Preface* states:
The Three Thefts and Three Powers are complete within one’s body,
The heart—*sovereign*—[44] turns and governs all things, each returning to its root.
*Qián* and *Kūn* [45] secure their positions, demons and evils are subdued,
The myriad lands are in harmony, bearing the sage’s grace.
Thus it is said:
*"Eat in accordance with the seasons, and all bones and joints will be in harmony.
Stir the mechanisms of the body, and all transformations will be at peace."*

This again follows the previous discourse on the Three Powers being at peace,
Therefore it says:
*"Eat in accordance with the seasons, and all bones and joints will be in harmony"*—
This means the student’s daily essentials:
Regulating the five viscera,
Eating and drinking must not be untimed.
If he does not lose the proper timing,
Then the three hundred sixty bones and joints,
Blood and *qi* flow unrestricted throughout the body,
No place remains blocked,
And ailments will not arise.
With his body now healthy and at ease,
He can nurture his spirit and embrace his *qi*,
Dwelling in the *Central Field* [46],
Taking *Huápú* [47] and *Yùyè* [48] elixirs seasonally
To irrigate the *Root of the Mysterious* [49],
And its shoots will flourish.

Thus *Laozi* [50] said:
*"When the world has the Dao,
Even warhorses are turned back to plow fields.
I alone differ from others,
Valuing the *Mother of the Ten Thousand Things* [51]."*

The stirring of its mechanism, all transformations finding peace—
This means when the first *Yáng* [52] stirs, one must immediately turn the *Dòugǎng* [53] mechanism to respond,
For each practice of the *Dao* brings vitality to all ten thousand spirits within the body.

The *Pure Yang True Person*’s *Gold Elixir Poetry* states:
*"Alone within the vast *Kàn* and *Kūn* [54] forms,*
*From the crown, meticulously refining the Primordial Function.*
*Wielding the *Beidou*’s [55] cunning heart-mechanism,*
*Inverting the *Nánchén* [56] with heroic resolve.*

Thus, the sage embodies the Heavenly Principle and acts in accordance with nature, governing the world without contrivance. Therefore, the people of the four seas rejoice in the nameless simplicity.

Thus *Laozi* says:
*"Practice the teaching of non-action.
I do nothing, yet the people transform themselves.
I love stillness, yet the people rectify themselves."*

The Dao/Way of Heaven and Earth is fluid, and thus yin and yang prevail—this means Heaven’s qi does not descend, Earth’s qi does not ascend, and the two do not communicate. Thus, Heaven and Earth are blocked, resulting in solitary yin and scarce yang. When the two qi become imbalanced, the five stars lose their courses, the sun and moon clash, the seasons fall out of order, winter thunders, summer snows, droughts and floods ravage the land, and all things wither.

Master Peng says:
*"When yang fire burns excessively, drought and flood go unchecked, turning winter into great heat.
When the *yinfu* (Yin Symbol) loses its rhythm, cold and warmth clash, turning summer into thick frost."*

If the Golden Palace fails to nurture the cinnabar and mercury, then pests and calamities arise—greatly, causing mountains to collapse and earth to split, with the Metal Tiger and Wood Dragon churning in chaos; or slightly, with violent rains and howling winds, as the *kan* (Water) male and *li* (Fire) female escape their bounds.

When yin and yang interact harmoniously, transformation flows naturally—this means yin and yang have the mystery of separation and union, and water and fire have the method of *ji* (completion). Gathering herbs according to the seasons and aligning with the stars, yin and yang naturally interact, and transformation flows in harmony. Thus, form and spirit are both perfected, and one attains true unity with the Dao.

The ode says:
*The Dao of nature is still, and all things thrive complete.
When yin and yang are misaligned, imbalance follows.
To grasp the reversal of yin and yang is to cast off old age,
returning to youth and matching Heaven’s longevity.*

Thus, the sage knows that the Dao/Way of nature cannot be defied and acts accordingly. The most profound stillness transcends even the measurements of calendars and divinations. Strange instruments give rise to all phenomena. The Eight Trigrams and Heavenly Stems conceal divine mechanisms. The arts of yin-yang victory are clearly manifested in their symbols.

Thus, this is the concluding summary of the essence within the three chapters of the *Yinfu Jing* (Yin Symbol Scripture).

The term *"sage"* is an honorific for those who embody virtue and power.

*"To know that the Dao/Way of nature cannot be defied"* means: Having understood that the Great Dao is the natural principle, one must uphold this natural Dao without deviation—seeking nothing else.

Thus, *"to act accordingly"* means: My body’s **qi**—like the **spirit-energy** of dragons and tigers—is hard to train and discipline, so I must follow the **cosmic cycles** and turn with the seasons, countering the **yin-yang revolutions** of the **Five Phases** to subdue it. A student who grasps this truth can refine the **elixir of immortality**.

*"The most profound stillness"* transcends even calendars and divinations: When the **inner alchemy** is complete, the **true emptiness** shines clear, like a sky without clouds for ten thousand *li*. At that moment, form and objects are forgotten, **nature** is still and boundless, and words and images cannot capture it—how could calendars and divinations ever measure this?

*"Strange instruments"* refers to the **Three Treasures** blended together, nurturing the **soul elixir** to pierce stone and transmute gold, changing at will—this is the **nameless instrument**, which is not strange at all? When a **great adept** possesses this **strange instrument**, they wield the **Great Transformation** as easily as one’s fingers, giving rise to the **Ten Thousand Phenomena**, the **Eight Trigrams**, and the **Heavenly Stems**.

*"The Eight Trigrams and Heavenly Stems conceal divine mechanisms; the arts of yin-yang victory are clearly manifested in their symbols"* means: The **divine spirit-energy** is fierce and unyielding; the **ghostly forces** submit and hide. When **yin is exhausted and yang is pure**, the **embryonic transformation** reaches its peak. From this point, the **spirit** ascends to dwell in the **cinnabar field** (the **brain’s upper cavity**), but one must tread firmly on the earth and carefully preserve it. When the **celestial gate** bursts open and the **yang spirit** seeks to emerge, do not let it stray lightly—wait until it is cherished like a newborn child, strong enough to walk, before the **spirit** can depart.

Thus it is said: There are **arts of yin-yang victory**; when the **inner work** is complete and the **outer practice** fulfilled, the **Celestial Sovereign** is naturally moved to send **imperial decrees** summoning you. Then, your body rides the **cloud chariot**, your **crane-like ascent** shines with **radiant light**, enveloping the **heavenly fragrance** of **imperial favor**, ascending to the **Jade Capital** and **Golden Gates**, entering the **palaces of the immortals** according to your **merits and cultivation**. Is this not the clear manifestation of the **arts of yin-yang victory** in their symbols?

Like **Yellow Emperor** of **Xuanyuan**, who ascended with his **consorts and ministers** seventy-two in number on a **dragon** from **Ba Mountain**; or **Emperor Shun**, who ascended in **Cangwu** at the **Five Elders’** home when they presented the **decree**; or **Zhang Daoling**, the **Celestial Master** of the **Han**, and **Xu Jingyang**, **Ge Xianweng** of the **Jin**, who all ascended with their **wives and children** in broad daylight to become **ministers of the Golden Gates**.

The **Dao of the Immortals** is indeed verified. How many **adepts** have there been from ancient times to today?

Students must not dismiss the **Immortal Way** as absurd and lose heart. The key is to **truly believe** and then seek a **worthy teacher** for direct transmission, diligently practicing without hesitation. Then, the **Heavenly Immortals** will naturally recommend you, and you will surely attain the **rank of the Immortal Sage**—this is no idle claim.

The **Hymn** says:
*"The embryonic immortal is nurtured, free from yin’s constraints,*
*Worshipping the **Highest Venerable** in the **Jade Void**.*
*The **arts of yin-yang victory** manifest clearly,*
*Soaring like cranes and phoenixes, riding the **cloud chariot**.*
*The **Yellow Emperor’s** *Yinfu Jing* **interprets and illuminates**,
*Completing the **volumes of the Way’s essence**."*

**Title:**
*The Yellow Emperor’s Yinfu Jing with Interlinear Commentary and Exegesis*
(*Huangdi Yinfu Jing Jiashong Jiezhu*)

**Author:**
Compiled by Daoist Wang Jie (style name Daoyuan) of the Yuan-Ming period. Three scrolls.
Source text: *Zhengtong Daozang*, *Tongzhen* section, *Yujue* category.

---

**Preface to the *Yellow Emperor’s Yinfu Jing* with Interlinear Commentary and Exegesis**

*"Heaven follows humanity, humanity follows Heaven"*—this is the purpose of the *Yinfu Jing*.

In antiquity, the Yellow Emperor, earnest in his devotion to the Dao, ascended Mount Kongtong to pay homage to Guangchengzi and inquire about the ultimate Way, receiving the secret precepts of returning to eternal life. Later, upon Mount Emei, he again paid homage to Huangren, who imparted the *Wuyaya-Sanyi* scriptures, which he kept secret and cultivated, thereby ascending to the highest immortality. Worried that future generations might lose the true teachings, he composed the *Yinfu Jing* in three sections—upper, middle, and lower—to correspond with the Three Powers (*san cai*), elucidating the marvels of *jing* (essence), *qi*, and *shen* (spirit) in their utmost refinement.

Yet fearing that mortals might not grasp the principle of return, he first declared: *"Observe the Dao of Heaven, grasp Heaven’s movements, and exhaust them."* This is the overarching framework of the three sections of the *Yinfu Jing*.

To know the Dao of Heaven, one must know the Dao of humanity;
to know the Dao of humanity, one must know the Dao of the Elixir (*dandao*);
to know the Dao of the Elixir, one must grasp the mechanics of yin-yang motion and stillness;
to grasp those mechanics, one must know the principles of internal and external return.

Knowing these principles, one refines lead and mercury without missing the proper moment, and governs the elixir fire without failing to observe its signs. As the text states: *"Cutting off the single source of profit, the adept’s effort is tenfold; three returns of day and night, the adept’s effort is ten-thousandfold."* This further teaches that the essence of cultivating the True lies in maintaining an unshaken resolve to gather and refine the mind and body, and secondarily, in applying unremitting *chou-tian* (withdrawal and addition) techniques without interruption.

The Way of *Quanzhen* is nothing else:
First, *jing* must be complete;
Second, *qi* must be complete;
Third, *shen* must be complete.

Fixing the gaze refines the spirit;
returning the hearing refines the essence;
sealing the speech refines the *qi*.

When these three completions and three truths are realized, they naturally merge within, and the True Fire polishes the embryo, forming a golden fetus. After ten months of work, yin is exhausted and yang is pure. At this moment, the fetus is shed, the spirit transforms, and the adept manifests without bounds, transcending birth and death to become an indestructible golden body—this is what is meant by *huan dan* (returning the Elixir).

I say that this text is concise yet profound in meaning. Those who fail to comprehend its teachings may seek explanations externally, straying from the Dao, and thus incur the guilt of presumption and madness. Therefore, I have sequentially explicated each passage of the Master’s secret precepts, supplemented with verse and verification, revealing the hidden mechanisms, awaiting those of like mind. I do not presume to exhaust the subject, but hope this may serve as an aid for beginners.

**The *Yin Fu Jing* Exegesis by Master Róngrán Zǐ Wáng Dàoyuán**

**Preface by Master Róngrán Zǐ Wáng Dàoyuán of Nánchāng’s Xiū River**

*"Heaven begets, heaven slays—this is the Dao’s principle.*
*In worldly terms, heaven begets yang, heaven slays yin. One yin, one yang—this is the Dao; one begetting, one slaying—this is principle.*

*Heaven begets in spring, when all things arise from yang—this is Heaven’s *ren* (benevolence).
*Heaven slays in autumn, when all things withdraw into yin—this is Heaven’s *yì* (righteousness).
*The waxing and waning of yin and yang—this is the Dao’s principle.*

*Thus, the Sage observes Heaven’s Dao, holds principle in mind, and governs the people with *wuwei* (non-action)—this is the Sage’s *ren*.
*He establishes the Five Punishments to harmonize the laws of the world—this is the Sage’s *yì*.
*The embodiment and function of *ren* and *yì*—this is the Sage’s Dao.*

*Speaking of Dao’s application: whenever the Winter Solstice arrives within one’s body, one must seal the pass and attain stillness, disperse the mind into fire, refine essence into *qi*, and advance the yang fire upward from the *Tai Xuang Gong* (Supreme Darkness Palace) to the *Nan Gong* (Southern Palace)—this is the principle of Heaven’s begetting.
*From this point onward, as yang reaches its peak and declines, a single yin arises beneath the five yangs, and one must then gather yang and withdraw the *Yin Fu* (Yin Symbol).
*Descending from the Jade Mountain to the Upper Capital, then to the Heavy Tower, sending it to the *Kun* position and halting—here, the martial fire is kindled to temper yin into yang—this is the principle of Heaven’s slaying.
*To circulate this within the body, continuous as if ever-present—is this not the Dao’s principle?

*Master Shao said:*
*‘When Qian meets Xun, observe the Moon Cavern;
When Earth meets Thunder, tread upon the Heavenly Root.’
*The Heavenly Root and Moon Cavern drift in leisure—
Thirty-six palaces are all spring.*

*Thus it is said:*
*‘The yang dragon and yin tiger coil in rotation,
Heaven’s hidden mechanisms of life and death unfold naturally.
Refined, the true seed of One-Nine emerges,
Within the vessel, spring overflows—Dao eternal.’*

---

**Heaven and Earth are the thieves of all things;
All things are thieves of humanity;
Humanity is the thief of all things.**

*Heaven and Earth are the thieves of all things*—this means Heaven and Earth generate all things, and the life and form of all things are formed by the interplay of yin and yang’s transformation. At every thought and impulse, Heaven and Earth know.
*Those who do good are protected by ghosts and spirits;
Those who do evil are struck by thunder and punishment*—this is how Heaven and Earth govern all things.

*All things are thieves of humanity*—this means all things arise alongside humanity, and within the human body dwell eighty-four thousand worms. Briefly stated: internally, the five viscera are consumed by *qí* and *huí* worms; externally, the skin is attacked by lice and fleas. As *Tan Jing Sheng*’s *Book of Transformation* says:
*‘The worms that camp within the belly
Plunder my vital *qi*, melt my spirit-soul,
Steal my flavors, yet live by them.’*
This is how all things steal from humanity.

*Humanity is the thief of all things*—this means humanity is the most refined of all things, encompassing within one mind the principles of all things. It learns from Heaven and Earth to know transformation, from spiders to weave nets, from bees to establish hierarchy, from moles to institute rites, from phoenixes to compose music, from ants to arrange armies. The Sage can take the principles of all things and perfect them within the self—this is how humanity steals from all things.

*In summary, the generation of Heaven, Earth, and humanity all lies within the Great Transformation. Forms steal from forms, things deceive things—none of this is outside the influence of yin and yang, the Five Phases’ *qi*. Only the Daoist, who comprehends the Three Thefts and transcends yin and yang, is free from the Three Corpses’ plunder.*

*Students should ponder this deeply.*

*Ode:*
*Heaven, Earth, and humanity share in all things’ birth,
Each family, each orifice holds its own spirit.
Forms steal from forms through yin and yang’s transformation—
The enlightened transcend the mundane, entering the Supreme Clarity.
The Three Thefts are resolved, the Three Powers are at peace.*

*This follows the earlier discussion of the Three Thefts, thus it says:*
*The Three Thefts resolved, the Three Powers secure*—this refers to the enlightened one, whose single nature illuminates all principles, who can discern that the body’s four elements are but yin and yang, the Five Phases’ *qi*, artificially combined. Unbound by form, one secretly practices the Symbol Fire to refine form and spirit. When spirit condenses and *qi* solidifies, this is the Golden Elixir’s great medicine, capable of slaying the Three Corpses’ worms. Once the Three Thefts are extinguished, the Three Powers naturally settle.

*As Master Shao said:*
*‘Having known all things are within me,
Why would I separately establish the Three Powers?’*

*Zhang Zǐyáng said:*
*‘Pursue the Two *Qi* along the Yellow Path,
Unite the Three Natures in the Primordial Palace.
When spirit is whole, there is no need for sleep;
When *qi* is whole, there is no need for food;
When essence is whole, there is no need for desire.
When practice reaches this point, how could the Three Powers be unstable?’*

*Ode:*
*The Three Thefts and Three Powers are complete within the body,
The Heart-Sovereign turns all things, each returning to root.
When Heaven and Earth’s positions are fixed, demons are subdued,
The myriad lands enjoy peace under the Sage’s grace.*

*Thus it is said:*
*‘Eat in season, and the hundred limbs harmonize.
Stir the mechanism, and all transformations settle.’*

*This further elaborates on the Three Powers being secure, thus it says:*
*‘Eat in season, and the hundred limbs harmonize’*—this means the practitioner must daily regulate the five viscera, ensuring meals are taken at their proper times. If no time is lost, then the three hundred sixty bones and blood-*qi* flow unimpeded throughout the body, with no place unnourished, and illness cannot arise. Having secured bodily health, one can then nurture spirit and embrace *qi*, dwelling eternally in the Central Field, drawing from the *Hua Chi* (Flower Pond) and *Yu Ye* (Jade Liquid) to irrigate the sacred root—its shoots will naturally flourish.
*As Laozi said:*
*‘When the Dao prevails in the world, even warhorses are used for manure—
I alone differ from others, valuing the Mother’s nourishment.’*

*‘Stir the mechanism, and all transformations settle’*—this means when the first yang stirs, one must immediately turn the Dipper’s handle to respond to it. Each practice of the Dao will make the myriad spirits within the body feel at ease.*"

chunks.original_text: 纯阳真人《金丹诗》曰：独处乾坤大象中，从头历历运元功。 纵横北斗心机巧，颅倒南辰胆气雄。 鬼哭神哀金鼎裂，鸡飞犬化玉炉空。 云何俗子寻常觅，大道希夷妙莫穷。 《丹经》曰：子细思量是妙哉，朝朝自劝紫霞杯。 若将地魄精擒缚，自有天魂祝寿来。 此之谓也。 颂曰：修真饮食要调停，一气冲和五脏清。 金液炼形神火煅，通身毫孔放光明。 人知其神之神，不知不神之所以神。 神之为言灵也，性也。 人之灵性，虚明无象。 在父母未生已前，不有其始； 居父母已生之后，不有其终。 至灵至圣，至幽至微，包含众体，总廓万灵，不生不灭，不方不圆。 白紫清真人故曰：此神不是思虑神，乃与元始相比肩是也。 此一节言学人平日修养工夫先以明性为主，心地之中常宜清静，不可容一毫私欲挂碍於心，亦不可着相求玄。 若才举个意思，神便不是神了。 经曰：夫人神好清而心扰之，此神全体之妙在乎心空无物，渊默含真，与太虚同其体，与日月同其明。 凡应事接物之间，以性随机，转应自然，三界圆通，此所以不知不神之所以神也。 张真人曰：视之不可见其形，及至呼之又却应。 《金刚经》云：世人以色相求我，以音声求我，是人行邪道，不得见如来。 斯言尽矣。 颂曰：一点元灵是至神，神知神处便非真。 人能了悟神虚体，朗朗真空不挂云。 日月有数，小大有定。 圣功生焉，神明出焉。 此承上云明性之体，於此故发明修命之用。 既得性住，叉复命关。 若能性命双修，方得形神俱妙。 夫修命之诀，学人可以观天之道，日月运行而有冬夏二至，阴阳停半而有卯酉二分，积日成月，积月成岁，是以日月有数而小大有定。 岂不闻日属阳，月属阴，月本无光，借日之光。 每月晦朔，太阴与太阳同宫交会，月至此时黑而无光； 月自初二初三离日渐远，日射光於月，生明而小，魂渐长魄渐消； 至初八日夜，光平上一半，乃曰上弦； 自此已往，至十五日夜，月与日相望，光明圆满而大，至此魂极而魄生； 十六、七日以下，魄长魂消，月光渐减； 至二十三日夜，光平下一半，乃曰下弦； 自此退至三十日夜，月光尽而又还晦矣。 周而复始，循环无穷，此天道运化自然而然，是以大修行人体此之理，运周天火候於一身。 所言日月者，精神也，水火也，铅汞也，性情也。 当作丹之时，以神合气，主固於内，飞神出在寅方，至申时进火，如日射光於月，渐渐生明而壮； 流精化气，直入泥丸，如月与日对望，继此阴生，用《青女传》言，退符下入坤宫，日月合璧，结成还丹，丹始结而小，功深渐养而大，故谓日月有数，小大有定也。 勤采勤收，时烹刻炼，真胎郁秀，智慧开通，故曰：圣功生焉，神明出焉。 颂曰：日月周天数往来，功施梵气结灵胎。 从微至着神超圣，火里栽莲朵朵开。 其盗机也，天下莫能见，莫能知。 君子得之固躬，小人得之轻命。 此承上云运行日月於一身，故得圣功生而神明出，於此故云：其盗机也者，此个盗字非世人窃盗之盗，乃运周天符火之法，一息工夫能夺天地一年造化。 《丹经》云：五行顺行，虎向水中生； 五行颠倒，龙从火里出。 行此道者，天地不能拘，甲子管不得，是以大修行人乃天地外一贼尔。

「The Pure Yang True Person’s *Alchemical Poems* state:
*Within the vast Dao of Heaven and Earth, alone I dwell,
From head to toe, each step refines the Primordial Essence’s work.
With nimble skill, I wield the Dipper’s Cross,
Boldly overturning the Southern Star’s mechanism—my *qi* as fierce as steel.*

*When the myriad spirits wail and demons lament, the golden cauldron cracks,
As roosters take flight and dogs dissolve, the jade furnace stands empty.*

*How can the common man seek such ordinary ways?
The Dao’s subtleties are boundless—its mysteries fathomless.*

*The *Alchemical Canon* says:
*‘Deliberate well—this is wondrous indeed!
Each dawn, I urge the *Zi Xia* [Purple Cloud] Cup to rise.’*

*If one binds the Earthly *Po* [embryo/soul] with precision,
The Heavenly *Hun* [ethereal soul] will naturally come to bless longevity.*

*Thus it is said.*

*Praise:
*To cultivate the True, one must balance food and breath.
A single *qi* harmonizes the Five Organs, cleansing them all.
The Golden Elixir refines the form, the Divine Fire tempers the spirit—
Every pore in the body radiates brilliance.*

*Men know the spirit’s spirit,
But fail to grasp the source of the non-spirit’s spirit.*

*The spirit, for its name, is *Ling* [numinous],
And *Xing* [inherent nature].*

*Before the parents were born, its beginning was not known;
After the parents were born, its end was not seen.*

*Most numinous, most sacred,
Most profound, most subtle—
It encompasses all forms,
It encompasses all spirits,
Unborn, unending,
Neither square nor round.*

*Thus the Pure and True True Person said:
*‘This spirit is not the spirit of deliberation,
But one that stands equal with the Primordial Origin.’*

*This passage speaks of how the student’s daily cultivation must first focus on clarifying inherent nature.
Within the heart-mind, one must always maintain purity and stillness,
Never allowing even a thread of private desire to obstruct it,
Nor clinging to forms while seeking the mysterious.*

*If one merely conjures an intention,
The spirit ceases to be spirit.*

*The *Sutra* says:
*‘The human spirit loves clarity, yet the heart disturbs it—
The spirit’s full brilliance lies in the heart’s emptiness, profound silence, and containing the True.
It shares its essence with the Great Void,
Its luminosity with the sun and moon.’*

*In all interactions with affairs and beings,
One must let inherent nature respond spontaneously,
Turning with the natural flow—
Thus the Three Realms are traversed in harmony,
And this is why one does not know the non-spirit’s source of spirit.*

*The True Person said:
*‘It cannot be seen, yet when called, it responds.’*

*The *Diamond Sutra* declares:
*‘If one seeks the Tathāgata through form and appearance,
Or through sound and voice,
They tread the wrong path and cannot see the Buddha.’*

*These words are complete.*

*Praise:
*A single point of Primordial Spirit is the ultimate numinous.
When the spirit knows itself, it is no longer true.
If one awakens to the spirit’s empty essence,
The resplendent void shines without a trace of cloud.*

*The sun and moon have their cycles,
The small and great have their limits.
From here arise the sacred works,
From here emerge the divine luminosities.*

*This follows the previous explanation of clarifying inherent nature,
And now reveals the method of cultivating life.*

*Having secured the dwelling of inherent nature,
One must then attend to the life-gate.*

*If one can cultivate both inherent nature and life,
Only then does the form and spirit attain perfect harmony.*

*The method of cultivating life is such:
The student may observe the Dao of Heaven,
Where the sun and moon revolve, marking the Winter and Summer Solstices,
And the Yin-Yang equilibrium at the Spring and Autumn Equinoxes.
Days accumulate into months,
Months accumulate into years—
Thus the sun and moon have their cycles,
And the small and great have their limits.*

*Has it not been heard?
The sun belongs to Yang, the moon to Yin;
The moon itself has no light, but borrows the sun’s.*

*At the month’s dark and new phases,
The Great Yin and Great Yang meet in the same palace,
And the moon, at this time, is dark and without light;
From the second to the third day, the moon gradually departs from the sun,
And the sun’s light shines upon it, generating a small brilliance—
The *Hun* grows, the *Po* diminishes.*

*By the eighth day, night and day share equal light—
This is called the Upper Crescent.*
*From here onward, until the fifteenth day at night,
The moon faces the sun, its light full and great—
At this point, the *Hun* reaches its peak, and the *Po* emerges.*

*From the sixteenth to the seventeenth days onward,
The *Po* grows, the *Hun* fades,
And the moon’s light gradually wanes.*

*By the twenty-third day at night,
The light is equally divided below—
This is called the Lower Crescent.*
*From here, until the thirtieth day at night,
The moon’s light fades completely, returning once more to darkness.*

*Thus it cycles endlessly, without end—
A natural and effortless movement of Heaven’s Dao.*
*Therefore, the great cultivator applies this principle within his own body,
And refines the *Fire Elucidation* [周天火候] of the Heavenly Cycle.*

*The sun and moon spoken of here are the spirit and *qi*,
Water and Fire,
Lead and Mercury,
And inherent nature and emotions.*

*When making the elixir,
One must merge spirit with *qi*,
Consolidating its foundation within,
And letting the spirit soar forth in the *Yin* [Tiger] Hour.
By the *Shen* [Monkey] Hour, one must increase the fire,
As the sun’s light shines upon the moon—
Gradually, the brilliance grows and strengthens.*

*The essence transforms into *qi*,
Directly entering the *Cinnabar Field* [泥丸],
As the moon faces the sun—
Following this, Yin emerges,
And according to the *Green Maiden Transmission* [《青女传》],
The elixir is withdrawn into the Earthly Palace,
Where the sun and moon join as one—
The elixir begins to form, small at first,
But with deep cultivation, it grows great—
Thus it is said: ‘The sun and moon have their cycles,
And the small and great have their limits.’*

*Diligently gather, diligently refine,
Timely cook and temper—
The True Embryo flourishes,
Wisdom and insight open wide—
Thus it is said: ‘From here arise the sacred works,
From here emerge the divine luminosities.’*

*Praise:
*The sun and moon cycle endlessly, their work applied—
The elixir’s essence is born from the *Dharma-qi* [梵气].*
*From the subtle to the manifest, the spirit transcends the sacred,
And within the fire, lotuses bloom one by one.*

*As for stealing the mechanism,
No one in the world can see or know it.*
*The noble man attains it and secures his body,
The petty man gains it and risks his life.*

*This follows the previous explanation of refining the sun and moon within one’s body,
And thus attaining the sacred works and divine luminosities—
Hence it is said:*

*‘The stealing here refers not to the worldly thievery of common men,
But to the method of refining the Heavenly Cycle’s elixir-fire—
In a single breath’s time, one can surpass a year’s transformation of Heaven and Earth.’*

*The *Alchemical Canon* says:
*‘When the Five Phases flow in order,
A tiger emerges from water;
When the Five Phases are inverted,
A dragon arises from fire.’*

*Those who practice this Dao
Cannot be confined by Heaven and Earth,
Nor bound by the *Bazi* [六十甲子, sixty-year Heavenly Stem-Earthly Branch cycle].*
*Thus, the great cultivator is a thief beyond Heaven and Earth.’*

chunks.original_text: 张紫阳所谓：工夫容易药非遥，岂非其盗机也哉？ 这个盗机至简至易，是谓无状之状，无象之象，是以天下莫能见，莫能知也。 君子之人得之，谦恭退隐，抱朴存真； 绝聪弃智，惟德为身； 损之又损，混俗同尘； 来者即应，无喜无嗔。 未尝显己之有道，此所以得之固躬也。 《老子》曰：我有三宝，保而持之，一曰慈，二曰俭，三曰不敢为天下先。 又曰：上德不德，是以有德是也。 小人之人若得此道，便要逞弄，不能伏藏，自是自大，自显自长，自伐自矜，欺人侮法，全无忌惮，薄德薄行，人皆忌之。 如是之人，未有不陷於害而轻於命，如庞涓之流是也。 经曰：自见者不明，自是者不彰，自伐者无功，自矜者不长，强梁者不得其死。 孔子故曰：小人反中庸，小人无忌惮也。 岂虚言哉？ 学人宜於此详察。

Zhang Wǔyáng said:

*"The practice is easy, but the medicine is not distant—
Is this not the very essence of the ‘thief’s method’?*

This ‘thief’s method’ is supremely simple, yet supremely subtle—
It is the form without form, the image without image.
Thus, none under Heaven can see it, none can know it.

The noble one who attains it
Is humble, retiring, and unassuming,
Nurtures simplicity and preserves authenticity;
Discards sharp intellect, relying solely on virtue as his body;
Diminishes further, blending with the mundane and dust;
Responds naturally to all that comes, without joy or anger.
He never flaunts his Dao—
This is how he holds it close to his essence.

As *Laozi* says:
*'I have three treasures, guarding and preserving them:
First, compassion;
Second, frugality;
Third, not daring to lead the world.'*
And again:
*'The highest virtue is without virtue—
Thus, it is truly virtuous.'*

The petty one, if he attains this Dao,
Will instead flaunt it, unable to conceal himself.
He grows arrogant, self-aggrandizing,
Boasting and vainglorious,
Deceiving others and scornful of the Way,
Completely without restraint,
With shallow virtue and shallow conduct—
All despise him.

Such a man has never failed to court harm
And risk his life—
Like Páng Juān’s kind.

The *Classical Text* says:
*'Those who praise themselves are blind,
Those who insist on being right are unilluminated,
Those who boast of their achievements gain no merit,
Those who brag of their virtue do not endure,
The overbearing meet no natural end.'*

Confucius thus said:
*'The petty one reverses the Mean—
The petty one has no restraint.'*

Is this not true speech?
The student should carefully examine this.

chunks.original_text: 颂曰：烧山符子盗天机，大象希形道隐微。 君子得之身退守，小人一得便胡为。 黄帝阴符经夹颂解注卷中竟 黄帝阴符经夹颂解注卷中 南昌修江混然子王道渊注 天生天杀，道之理也。 以世法言，天生阳也，天杀阴也，一阴一阳之谓道，一生一杀之谓理。 天生於春，万物发生於阳，天之仁也； 天杀於秋，万物收敛於阴，天之义也。 阴阳消长，道之理也。 是以圣人观天之道，执理於心，以无为而化天下之民，圣人之仁也； 以五刑而齐天下之法，圣人之义也。 仁义体用，圣人之道也。 以道用言，凡遇身中冬至之时，则当闭关静定，飞意化火、炼精为气，督进阳火，从太玄宫提上南宫，此天生之理也。 至此已往阳极而亏，故一阴生于五阳之下，则当敛阳而退阴符。 从玉山上京下重楼，送至坤位而止，发武火煅炼，烹阴为阳，此天杀之理也。 运用一身，绵绵若存，岂不是道之理也？ 邵子曰：乾遇巽时观月窟，地逢雷处蹑天根。 天根月窟闲来往，三十六宫都是春。 如斯之谓也。 颂曰：阳龙阴虎两盘旋，生杀天机理自然。 炼出一九真种子，壶中春满道绵绵。 天地，万物之盗； 万物，人之盗； 人，万物之盗。 天地，万物之盗者，此谓天地生万物，万物之性命，莫不由乎阴阳运化结成其形。 举心动念处，天地皆知。 作其善者，鬼神护佑； 作其恶者，雷霆典刑，此天地所以万物也。 万物，人之盗者，此言万物之生与人并作，人身之内生八万四千虫，今略言之，内则五脏被蛲蛔所食，外则皮肤被蚤虱所攻。 谭景升《化书》所谓：虫营虰者，腹中之虫也。 搏我精气，铄我魂魄，盗我滋味，而有其生。 此万物所以盗人也。 人，万物之盗者，此言人为万物至灵，一心包含万物之理，师天地而知运化，师蜘味而结网罟，师蜜蜂而立君臣，师拱鼠而制礼，师鸣凤而作乐，师蝼蚁而设兵阵。 圣人能取万物之理以致一身，此人所以盗万物也。 总而言之，天地人物之生，皆在大化之中，形形相盗，物物相欺，无非阴阳五行之气使之而然也。 唯有道者了明三盗，超出阴阳之外，则无三尸所盗之害也。 学者宜玩味焉。 颂曰：天地人同万物生，一家一窍各含灵。 形形相盗阴阳化，悟者超凡入太清。 三盗既宜，三才既安。 此承上云三盗之义，於此故云：三盗既宜者，此所谓有道之人一性觉照，万理贯通，自能勘破一身四大是阴阳五行之气假合而生，我则不被形缚，但密行符火以炼形神，神凝气结，是谓金丹大药有能杀灭三尸之虫，既得三盗绝灭，自然三才安矣。 邵子所谓：既知万物备於我，肯把三才别立根。 张紫阳故曰：追二气於黄道，会三性於元宫，神全不思睡，气全不思食，精全不思欲，工夫至此，何患乎三才不安矣？ 颂曰：三盗三才备一身，心君转物各归根。 乾坤定位邪魔伏，万国清平荷圣恩。 故曰：食其时，百骸理。 动其机，万化安。 此又承上云三才既安之义，於此故曰：食其时，百骸理者，此言学人平日大要，调和五脏，饮食不可失其时。 苟无失其时，则通身三百六十骨节血气周流，无处不畅，而病患自不生。 既得其身体康泰，可以栖神抱气，常住中田，依时取华池玉液之浆浇权灵根，其苗自秀。 《老子》故曰：天下有道，却走马以粪，我独异於人，而贵食母是也。

「The *Preface* states:
The *Burning Mountain* [1] seals the Dao of Heaven’s theft,
The *Great Symbol* [2] hides the subtle mysteries of the Way.
The virtuous one attains it and retreats to preserve himself,
While the petty one, once he gains it, acts recklessly.

*Yellow Emperor’s Obscure Precepts* [3]—*Interpretation of the Interspersed Precepts*—[4] therein concludes:
*Yellow Emperor’s Obscure Precepts* [3]—*Interpretation of the Interspersed Precepts*—[4]—[5] *Master Rúndàoyuān* of *Nánchāng Xiūjiāng* [6] annotates:
Heaven’s birth and Heaven’s death are the Way’s principle.
Speaking in terms of worldly law,
Heaven’s birth is *yang* [7], Heaven’s death is *yin* [8];
One *yin* and one *yang* is called the Way,
One birth and one death is called principle.

Heaven’s birth occurs in spring,
When all things arise from *yang*—Heaven’s benevolence;
Heaven’s death occurs in autumn,
When all things withdraw into *yin*—Heaven’s righteousness.
The ebb and flow of *yin* and *yang* are the Way’s principle.

Thus, the sage observes Heaven’s Way,
Holds principle within his heart,
And transforms the people of the world through non-action—this is the sage’s benevolence;
With the five punishments [9], he harmonizes the laws of the world—this is the sage’s righteousness.
Benevolence and righteousness in essence and application are the sage’s Way.

Speaking in terms of application,
When one encounters the winter solstice [10] within his body,
He must close the gate [11] and remain still,
Sending his mind aloft to transform fire,
Refining essence into *qi*,
Advancing the *yang* fire,
From the *Tàixuān Palace* [12] drawing upward to the *Nán Palace* [13]—this is Heaven’s birth principle.

Once this is done, the *yang* reaches its peak and declines,
So when one *yin* arises beneath the five *yang*,
He must withdraw the *yang* and suppress the *Obscure Precept* of *yin*.
From *Yùshān* [14] descending to *Chónglóu* [15],
Conveying it to the *Kūn* [16] position and halting,
Igniting the *Martial Fire* [17] to temper and refine,
Cooking *yin* into *yang*—this is Heaven’s death principle.

Cultivating within one’s body,
Continuously as if sustained—
Is this not the Way’s principle?

When *Qián* [19] meets *Xùn* [20], observe the *Moon Cavern* [21];
When earth encounters *léi* [22], tread upon Heaven’s root.
Heaven’s root and Moon Cavern come and go at leisure,
Thirty-six palaces [23] are all spring.
This is what is meant.

The *yang* dragon and *yin* tiger intertwine in circles,
Heaven’s birth and death principles unfold naturally.
Refining yields the *One Nine* [24] true seed,
A caldron full of spring—Dao stretches endlessly.

Heaven and Earth are the thieves of all things;
All things are thieves of man;
Man is the thief of all things.
Heaven and Earth are the thieves of all things—
This means Heaven and Earth generate all things,
And the vitality of all things,
None escape the *yin-yang* transformations that form their bodies.
Every thought and intention—Heaven and Earth know them all.
Doing good brings protection from spirits and gods;
Doing evil invites punishment by thunder and lightning—
This is how Heaven and Earth treat all things.

All things are thieves of man—
This means all things arise alongside man,
And within the human body, eight thousand four hundred insects [25] thrive.
Speaking briefly,
Internally, the five viscera [26] are consumed by *wēngzhì* [27] worms,
Externally, the skin is attacked by fleas and lice.
As *Tán Jǐngshēng*’s *Book of Transformation* [28] says:
*Wēngzhì* [29] insects, the worms of the belly,
Struggle with my *qi* and essence,
Melt my spirit and soul,
Steal my nourishment,
And yet sustain their own lives.
This is how all things steal from man.

Man is the thief of all things—
This means man is the most refined of all things,
One mind encompassing the principles of all things,
Learning from Heaven and Earth to know transformations,
Learning from the *spider* to weave nets,
Learning from the *bee* to establish hierarchy,
Learning from the *gopher* to create rituals,
Learning from the *phoenix* to compose music,
Learning from the *ant* to arrange armies and formations.
The sage can extract the principles of all things to perfect himself—
This is how man steals from all things.

In summary,
The birth of Heaven, Earth, and man,
All lie within the Great Transformation [30],
Each form stealing from another,
Each thing deceiving another,
None but the *yin-yang* and Five Phases *qi* [31] acting thus.
Only the Daoist who understands the Three Thefts [32],
Transcending beyond *yin-yang*,
Will escape the harm of the Three Corpses [33] stealing from him.
The student should ponder this well.

The *Preface* states:
Heaven, Earth, and man share the birth of all things,
Each family and orifice holds its own spirit.
Forms steal from forms through *yin-yang* transformations,
The enlightened transcend the mundane to enter *Tàiqīng* [34].
The Three Thefts [35] being understood,
The Three Powers [36] are at peace.
This follows the previous discourse on the Three Thefts,
Therefore it says:
When the Three Thefts are understood,
The Three Powers are at peace—
This refers to the Daoist,
Whose singular nature is awakened and illuminated,
Whose myriad principles are unified,
Who can discern that the body’s Four Great Elements [37]
Are but *yin-yang* and Five Phases *qi* falsely combined.
He is not bound by form,
But secretly practices the *Obscure Precept* fire
To refine body and spirit.
When spirit condenses and *qi* solidifies,
This is called the *Great Elixir* [38],
A medicine capable of annihilating the Three Corpses [33].
Once the Three Thefts are extinguished,
The Three Powers naturally rest.

As *Master Shào* says:
When one knows all things are complete within me,
Why would he separately establish the Three Powers?

*Zhāng Zǐyáng* [39] thus said:
*"Chasing the Two Qì [40] along the Yellow Dao [41],
Uniting the Three Natures [42] in the Primordial Palace [43],
The spirit is whole and does not crave sleep,
The *qi* is whole and does not crave food,
The essence is whole and does not crave desire—
When cultivation reaches this point,
What fear is there that the Three Powers will not be at peace?"*

The *Preface* states:
The Three Thefts and Three Powers are complete within one’s body,
The heart—*sovereign*—[44] turns and governs all things, each returning to its root.
*Qián* and *Kūn* [45] secure their positions, demons and evils are subdued,
The myriad lands are in harmony, bearing the sage’s grace.
Thus it is said:
*"Eat in accordance with the seasons, and all bones and joints will be in harmony.
Stir the mechanisms of the body, and all transformations will be at peace."*

This again follows the previous discourse on the Three Powers being at peace,
Therefore it says:
*"Eat in accordance with the seasons, and all bones and joints will be in harmony"*—
This means the student’s daily essentials:
Regulating the five viscera,
Eating and drinking must not be untimed.
If he does not lose the proper timing,
Then the three hundred sixty bones and joints,
Blood and *qi* flow unrestricted throughout the body,
No place remains blocked,
And ailments will not arise.
With his body now healthy and at ease,
He can nurture his spirit and embrace his *qi*,
Dwelling in the *Central Field* [46],
Taking *Huápú* [47] and *Yùyè* [48] elixirs seasonally
To irrigate the *Root of the Mysterious* [49],
And its shoots will flourish.

Thus *Laozi* [50] said:
*"When the world has the Dao,
Even warhorses are turned back to plow fields.
I alone differ from others,
Valuing the *Mother of the Ten Thousand Things* [51]."*

The stirring of its mechanism, all transformations finding peace—
This means when the first *Yáng* [52] stirs, one must immediately turn the *Dòugǎng* [53] mechanism to respond,
For each practice of the *Dao* brings vitality to all ten thousand spirits within the body.

The *Pure Yang True Person*’s *Gold Elixir Poetry* states:
*"Alone within the vast *Kàn* and *Kūn* [54] forms,*
*From the crown, meticulously refining the Primordial Function.*
*Wielding the *Beidou*’s [55] cunning heart-mechanism,*
*Inverting the *Nánchén* [56] with heroic resolve.*
*Ghosts wail, gods lament as the Golden Cauldron cracks,*
*Roosters take flight, dogs transmute—*
*The Jade Furnace stands empty.*
*How can the vulgar seeker grasp this commonplace?*
*The *Dao*’s profundity is boundless, its mysteries unfathomable."*

The *Alchemical Classic* says:
*"Carefully ponder this marvel—*
*Each dawn, urging the *Zǐxīa* [57] cup to its depths.*
*If you seize the *Earth’s Soul* [58] with precision,*
*Then the *Heavenly Spirit* [59] will naturally bestow longevity."*

Thus it is said:

*Ode:*
*"Cultivation’s diet must be balanced and regulated,*
*The *Qi* harmonized, the five viscera cleansed.*
*The Golden Elixir refines form, the *Shénhuǒ* [60] tempers essence,*
*Every pore in the body radiates luminous clarity."*

Men know the *shén* of *shén* [61],
But do not know the *non-shén* of *shén*’s essence.
For *shén*—this word for *ling* [62], for *xìng* [63]—
Is the human’s luminous, formless nature.
Before parents conceived, it had no beginning;
After birth, it has no end.
Most subtle, most sacred,
Most profound, most refined,
It encompasses all forms,
Embraces all spirits,
Neither born nor destroyed,
Neither square nor round.

The *White-Purple Pure True Person* thus declared:
*"This *shén* is not the *shén* of deliberation,*
*But stands equal to *Yuānshǐ* [64] himself."*

This section speaks of the student’s daily cultivation—
First, one must clarify the nature,
Keeping the heart-mind ever serene,
Free of even a thread of private desire.
Nor should one cling to forms while seeking the mysterious.
If but a thought arises,
The *shén* is no longer *shén*.

The *Classic* says:
*"The human *shén* loves clarity, yet the mind disturbs it.
The marvel of the *shén*’s entirety lies in the heart’s emptiness—
Silent, containing truth,
In harmony with the *Tàixū* [65],
As luminous as the sun and moon."*

In all interactions and encounters,
One’s nature responds spontaneously,
Turning with the *Three Realms* [66] in perfect unity—
Thus the saying: *"One does not know the *non-shén* of *shén*."*

The *True Person Zhang* said:
*"It cannot be seen, yet when called, it responds."*

The *Diamond Sutra* states:
*"Worldly beings seek me through form and sound—
These are the paths of delusion,
And they cannot see the *Thus-Come One*."*

Thus it is said:

*Ode:*
*"A single point of Primordial Spirit is the utmost *shén*,
Yet when the *shén* knows its dwelling, it is no longer true.
If one awakens to the *shén*’s empty essence,
The boundless true void shines without obstruction."*

The sun and moon follow their cycles,
Small and great have their fixed measures.
From this, the sacred function arises,
And the divine luminosity emerges.

This follows the earlier discussion of clarifying the nature’s essence,
And thus expounds the method of nurturing life.
Having settled the nature,
One must then address the *mìng* [67].
If both nature and life are cultivated together,
Only then will form and *shén* both attain perfection.

The secret of nurturing life:
The student may observe the *Dao* of Heaven—
The sun and moon revolve, marking the *Winter* and *Summer Solstices*,
*Yīn* and *Yáng* pause at the *Mao-Yǒu Divisions* [68],
Days accumulate into months, months into years—
Thus the sun and moon have their numbers,
Small and great their fixed measures.

Has it not been said:
*The sun belongs to *Yáng*, the moon to *Yīn*,
The moon itself has no light, borrowing the sun’s radiance.*
At the *new moon* and *full moon*,
The *Great Yin* and *Great Yang* meet in the same palace,
And the moon, at this time, is dark and without light;
From the second and third days onward,
The moon drifts farther from the sun,
And the sun’s light strikes it—
Its brilliance grows, yet it remains small,
The *hún* [69] lengthens while the *pò* [70] diminishes;
By the eighth day’s night,
Its light is half-illuminated above—
This is called the *Upper Crescent*;
From this point onward, until the fifteenth night,
The moon faces the sun, its light full and vast—
At this juncture, the *hún* reaches its peak while the *pò* arises;
On the sixteenth and seventeenth days,
The *pò* grows while the *hún* wanes,
And the moon’s light gradually diminishes;
By the twenty-third night,
Its light is half-illuminated below—
This is called the *Lower Crescent*;
From this retreat until the thirtieth night,
The moon’s light fades entirely, returning to darkness once more.
This cycle repeats endlessly, without end—
A natural unfolding of Heaven’s transformations.
Thus, the great practitioner embodies this principle within oneself,
Circulating the *Zhōutiān* [71] fire and timing within the body.

The *sun* and *moon* refer to:
*Shén* and *qì*, water and fire, lead and mercury, nature and emotion.
When refining the elixir,
One merges *shén* with *qì*,
Consolidating within—
The *shén* flies forth to the *Yín* direction,
By *Shēn* hour, the fire advances,
As the sun’s light strikes the moon,
Its brilliance grows and strengthens;
The *jīng* [72] flows, transforming into *qì*,
Straight into the *Níhuán* [73],
As the moon faces the sun—
Following this, *Yīn* arises,
Using the *Qīngnǚ* [74]’s words,
The *Fù* symbol retreats downward into the *Kūn* palace,
The sun and moon unite in harmony,
Forming the *Returning Elixir*—
At first, the elixir is small,
But with deepened practice, it grows vast—
Thus it is said: *"The sun and moon have their numbers,
Small and great their fixed measures."*

Diligently gather, diligently refine,
Timely cooking and tempering—
The true embryo flourishes,
Wisdom opens fully—
Thus it is said:
*"The sacred function arises,
And the divine luminosity emerges."*

*Ode:*
*"The sun and moon revolve in their celestial cycles,*
*The *Dàfàn* [75] *qi* refines the sacred embryo.*
*From the subtle to the manifest, the *shén* transcends the sacred,*
*Lotus blossoms unfold within the fire."*

Its mechanism is stolen—
None in the world can see it,
None can know it.
The virtuous man who attains it guards it within himself,
While the petty man who grasps it risks his life.

This follows the discussion of circulating the sun and moon within the body,
Thus the sacred function arises and the divine luminosity emerges—
Hence it is said:
*"Its mechanism is stolen"*—
This *thief* is not the common thief of the world,
But the method of circulating the *Zhōutiān* fire-symbols.
A single breath’s work can surpass Heaven and Earth’s year-long transformations.

The *Alchemical Classic* says:
*"The Five Phases move in order,
And the tiger emerges from the water."*

The Five Phases inverted—
The dragon emerges from the fire.

Practitioners of this Dao/Way
Cannot be confined by Heaven and Earth,
Nor restrained by the *jiǎzǐ* cycle.
Hence, the great adept becomes
A thief beyond the bounds of Heaven and Earth.

As Zhang Ziyang said:
*"The practice is easy, the medicine is not far away—
Is this not the stolen mechanism?"*

This stolen mechanism is supremely simple and easy,
The state of the formless form,
The symbol of the shapeless symbol—
Thus none in the world can see it,
None can know it.

The virtuous man who attains it
Is humble, modest, and withdraws,
Holding fast to purity and preserving truth;
Abandoning sharp intellect, discarding cleverness,
He alone lets *virtue/power* be his body;
Diminishing further, diminishing yet again,
Merging with the common, blending with the dust;
Responding to what comes, without joy or anger.
He never openly proclaims his attainment of the Dao/Way—
This is why he who possesses it guards it within himself.

The *Laozi* says:
*"I have three treasures,
Preserve and uphold them:
The first is compassion,
The second is frugality,
The third is not daring to act before all under Heaven."*

And again:
*"The highest virtue/power is without virtue/power—
Thus it is said: 'He who has virtue/power is truly virtuous/powerful.'"*

Will surely flaunt it,
Unable to conceal himself—
Self-aggrandizing, self-proclaiming,
Self-praising, self-boasting,
Cheating others and defying the *dharma*,
Completely without restraint,
Shallow in virtue/power and shallow in practice—
All men despise him.

To fall into harm and risk his life,
Like Páng Juān of old.

The scripture says:

Those who insist on their own ways are not renowned,
Those who praise themselves achieve no merit,
Those who boast of themselves do not endure,
The overbearing meet no peaceful death."*

Thus Confucius said:
*"The petty man inverts the *zhōngyōng*,
The petty man is without restraint."*
Is this not true?

The student should carefully examine this.
